Graphical abstract This work explored the ammonia storage/release behaviors of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst in selective catalytic reduction of NO. Results displayed that the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 performed much higher NO removal rate than the theoretical maximum if the NH3/NO ratio was lower than one, which was due to the ammonia storage/release behaviors. The ammonia storing was more likely to occur at low temperatures, and the storage capacity of the catalyst reached 27 μmol m−2 at 50 °C. Moreover, ammonia exists mainly on physical form of temperatures below 250 °C and is adsorbed in weakly acidic sites; while high temperature strengthen activation of strong acid sites, resulting in increasing the ammonia storage at 350 °C. NH3-TPD results showed two peaks of ammonia desorption, indicating the weak and strong acid sites of the catalyst. The ammonia storage/release curves at Constant Temperature Flow Field were asymmetric and BET isotherm showed Type H3 hysteresis loop, which was caused by mass transfer in the plate-like pore structure formed by the particle polymerization. The porous structure and highly dispersed active components were beneficial for storing ammonia. The effective utilization ratio of the stored ammonia decreased with the increasing temperature and GHSV. Keywords NO removal CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst Ammonia storage Ammonia release Ammonia species 1 Introduction According to current reports, haze of sulfuric acid type has gradually changed to nitric acid type [1]. The reduction of nitrogen oxides (deNOx) has been the emphasis of mitigation on atmospheric pollution. Selective catalytic reduction by NH3 (NH3-SCR) has become the most widely used technology for NOx removal owing to its high efficiency. The catalyst is the key to NH3-SCR technology. Ceria-based deNOx catalysts possess the feature of environment amity, high catalytic activity, and wide active temperature range. Hence, the ceria-based deNOx catalyst has been designated as the substitute of V2O5(WO3)/TiO2 catalyst by Chinese ministries and commissions [2]. Interestingly, there was a unique phenomenon in industrial deNOx applications of the ceria-based catalysts. The deNOx efficiency increased slowly after the ammonia injection started, and then reached the best stable value. After the NH3 closure, deNOx efficiency would stabilize for a period of time and then decreased (Support information, Fig. S1). In most cases of industrial application, power or boiler load was unstable and caused the concentration of NOx fluctuating, but the ammonia injection system is unable to respond in time. However, ceria-based catalysts can still keep stable catalytic efficiency in this circumstance. This phenomenon verified that ceria-based catalyst possesses some distinctive properties of ammonia storage/release. As well known, ceria has remarkable capacity of oxygen storage/release [3–7]. It has been proved that the high mobility of oxygen vacancy and a large amount of oxygen free radicals provided by the transformation between Ce3+ and Ce4+ can accelerate the deNOx process [8–12]. The adsorption and activation of ammonia during the process has been extensively studied while ammonia storage/release was not involved [13–16]. Catalytic systems involved were mostly V/Ti catalysts. In V/Ti catalysts, NH3 is usually present in the form of adsorbed NH3 (Lewis acid sites) and NH4 + (Brønsted acid sites) in most of the reports [15,17–20]. Inhak Song et al. [21] concluded that the Brønsted acid sites (B-acid sites) were mostly originated from VOHTi or TiOHT i. Ramis et al. [22] held the view that ammonia absorbed on Lewis acid sites (L-acid sites) firstly and then dehydrogenate to NH2 which react with phase NO to generate the intermediate NH2NO. Topsoe et al. [23] proposed that ammonia absorbed on the B-acid sites in the form of -NH4 + and then oxidized to NH3 + via V5+O. Accordingly, HOV 4+ was oxidized to V5+ O by oxygen. Arnarson et al. [24] demonstrated that B-acid sites captured NH3 and enhanced the stability of NH4 +, which has a negative impact on the catalytic activity. The study of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst showed that ammonia only adsorbed on L-acid sites could directly react with NO [25]. This indicated that the B-acid sites played the role of providing the NH3 molecule for the L-acid sites but not facilitated the reaction process directly. In a word, the ammonia adsorption and the oxidative dehydrogenation progress play the most important roles during the SCR reaction whether it is adsorbed at L-acid sites or B-acid sites [26–28]. Zeolite catalysts have been widely studied currently in the concept of ammonia storage/release. According to relevant reports, ammonia usually stored in the form of chemical or physical adsorption on zeolite deNOx catalysts [29,30]. Research about Cu-ZSM-5 catalyst depicted that ammonia could bound to the copper sites or adsorb on B-acid sites and the storage behavior was affected by properties of ion-exchanged. Additionally, H2O stored on copper sites will lower the binding strength of ammonia to the zeolite framework [31]. Similar phenomena were found in hollow beta zeolite catalysts which encapsulated with different iron species. Furthermore, the doping of sodium and phosphorus would weaken the strength of acid sites and reduce the ammonia storage correspondingly. Moreover, L-acid sites showed more attribution to ammonia adsorption in Fe-Containing BEA zeolites catalyst during NH3-SCR reaction [32]. Hamoud et al. [33] found that ammonia was stored in the form of adsorbed NH3 and NH4 + in Fe-MOR and Cu-CZC. Besides, experiments demonstrated that the porous structure also affected ammonia storage and the storage amount descended with temperature increasing [34,35]. The purpose of previous reports was to explore the contribution of stored NH3 for catalytic activities, namely the higher the NH3 adsorption, the higher the catalytic efficiency. However, those researches did not cover the storage of excess ammonia. Under industrial working conditions, the ceria-based deNOx catalyst displayed different ammonia storage/release characteristics in the SCR reaction, as shown in Support information (Fig. S1). According to our previous study, the representative CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst with remarkable deNOx capability was selected [36]. The samples were prepared via method of wet impregnation and the NO conversions at low NH3/NO ratios were studied. Constant Temperature Flow Field was designed to explore the NH3 storage/release behaviors. The temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (in situ DRIFT) techniques were used to study the acidic position, forms and species of the stored- ammonia. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation The CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 was prepared via method of wet impregnation and the support was TiO2 (powder). Ceria nitrate, stannic chloride and ammonium molybdate (molar ratio of Ce/Sn/Mo = 5:1:3) were dissolved in distilled water and the mixed solution was stirred to clear. Then TiO2 powder was mixed into the clarified solution. The sample was obtained via the method of extrusion molding after mixing and aging. The sample was dried at 90 °C for 24 h in an oven and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace finally. 2.2 Measurements of catalyst activity and the ammonia storage/release amount The measurements of catalytic activity were carried out in a fix-bed quartz reactor (10 mm of inner diameter) using 8.0 mL catalyst (Fig. 1 ). The details could be seen in the Supporting Information (SI). The amount of ammonia storage/release was explored in self-built instrument (Fig. 2 ). The sample was dried for 24 h, 10 mL of the catalyst was measured and filled into the fix-bed quartz reactor. Then the fixed bed temperature was raised to the target temperature. Pure ammonia was pumped into the reactor after the reading was stable. When the reading was no longer rising (ammonia storage saturated) the pure ammonia was closed. Afterwards, the device was connected to the air atmosphere to release weakly-stored ammonia. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst XRD patterns were obtained on D-MAX/RB (Smartlab TM 3 kW, Rigaku) with Cu/Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). The micromorphology of the catalyst’s transverse was characterized on a JSM-5900 with pretreatment of spraying gold. NH3-TPD was conducted on the CHEMBET-3000. The catalysts were preheated at 500 °C for 1 h under a helium stream and cooled to 50 °C for ammonia adsorption. BET-surface area, pore size, pore volume and N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured on the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 automatic equipment at 77.3 K. In situ DRIFT experiments were conducted on Nicolet iS50 spectrometer, prior to each experiment, the catalysts were heated in N2 at 500 °C for 1 h to remove the moisture and other adsorbents, and then cooled to 50 °C. Before injecting ammonia, background spectra were recorded during the cooling process at 400 °C, 350 °C, 300 °C, 250 °C, 200 °C, 150 °C, 100 °C and 50 °C. Afterwards, 10,000 ppm NH3 was pumped into the reactor for 1 h at 50 °C, the total gas flow rate was 100 mL min−1 and N2 was used as the balance gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance 3.1.1 Effects of NH3/NO ratios on the catalytic activity Fig. 3 (a) depicted the NO conversion of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6OX/TiO2 at different NH3/NO ratios. NO can theoretically be fully converted only when the NH3/NO ratio was 1 according to the Equation (2). Interestingly, it could be seen that the NO conversions were all higher than the theoretical maximum among the active temperature interval (250 °C–450 °C) when the NH3/NO ratio was low (0.5−0.9). The excess NO conversion was ascribed to unique ammonia release behavior. Nevertheless, part of released ammonia might slip from the reactor directly or be oxidized during the ammonia release process but not react with NO. For convenience, we denoted released ammonia reacting with NO as effective released ammonia. It’s obvious that the curves of NO conversion under different NH3/NO ratios depicts trends that: When the NH3/NO ratios were 0.5 and 0.6, the catalytic activity raised rapidly within 200 °C–250 °C. This implied that the catalyst released ammonia rapidly and most of them had been activated at 250 °C. Furthermore, the NO conversion peak (above 90 %) appeared within 250 °C–300 °C and maintained stable which was much higher than the theoretical maximum (50％ and 60％). The catalytic activity decreased significantly within 300 °C–350 °C, indicating that the amount of effective released-ammonia was drastically reduced. Then the catalytic activity decreased slowly in the range of 350 °C–500 °C but there was still 10 % surplus activity. This might be attributed to strongly-stored ammonia which released slowly at high temperature. In contrast, it is not difficult to conclude that the high activity peak at low temperature was caused by the rapid release of weakly-stored ammonia. When the NH3/NO ratio rose to 0.7 and 0.8, the catalytic activity showed a similar phenomenon as above. The catalytic activity was close to 100 % in the range of 300 °C–350 °C. This implied that the catalyst had a high and stable effective ammonia release rate at this temperature window. The active temperature window widened to higher temperature for 50 °C–100 °C compared to the NH3/NO ratio of 0.5 and 0.6. This was because the required supplementary ammonia decreased with the NH3/NO ratio increasing and the stored ammonia would release slowly within the active temperature window. Then the catalytic activity slowly decreased as above due to the reduction of the amount of weakly stored ammonia supplied and the slow release of strongly stored ammonia. Continue to increase the NH3/NO ratio and found that the catalytic activities curve at the NH3/NO ratio of 0.9 was similar with that when NH3/NO ratio reached 1. The catalytic NO conversion was close to 100 % within 250 °C–450 °C. This was ascribed to the increase of ammonia supply in real-time caused by the increased NH3/NO ratio. Hence, although released less effective ammonia, it could also maintain high catalytic activity over a wider temperature window. To verify whether the excess catalytic activity was caused by the ammonia storage of the catalyst, another group of experiments was designed for comparison. The reaction gases were injected to the reactor after the temperature increased to 250 °C and keep stable firstly (the NH3/NO ratio was controlled to be 0.5 and 0.6 respectively). The NO conversion was shown in Fig. 3(b). It could be observed that there was no catalytic activity peak at 250 °C and there was hardly any residual NO conversion within the catalytic active temperature window compared with Fig. 3(a). This demonstrated that the behavior of ammonia storage was carried out at low temperature (＜250 °C) previously, and the rapid release of ammonia occurred with the temperature rising to the active window. In order to study the effects of NH3/NO ratios on the catalytic effective NH3 release more intuitively, NO was applied as a molecular probe to explore the quantity of effective NH3 release. The quantity of catalytic effective NH3 release was calculated as Eq. (1). The released ammonia couldn’t be detected effectively when the NH3/NO ratio was 1 because there was no excess NO to be reacted in this case. Hence, Fig. 4 just depicted the amount of catalytic effective ammonia release when the NH3/NO ratios were 0.5, 0.6, 0.7, 0.8 and 0.9. (1) N H 3 e f f , r e = N O x i n - N O x o u t N O x i n × 100 % - N H 3 N O × 100 % × N O x i n ( 1 ) The results illustrated that the quantity of effective NH3 release decreased at 250 °C–300 °C when the NH3/NO ratio increased. This is because there was no surplus NO to react when the NH3/NO ratio get higher. Consequently, the potential of catalytic effective ammonia release could be reflected more accurately at low NH3/NO ratio through the activity change of CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2. It was found that the quantity of catalytic effective NH3 release increased firstly and then gradually decreased when the NH3/NO ratio was 0.8, 0.7 and 0.6. Moreover, the maximum quantity of NH3 release occurred at 250 °C at the NH3/NO ratio of 0.5. After reaching the maximum value, the release amount decreased as the temperature increased. This may be because the premature release of large amount of stored ammonia induced by excessive NO. This showed that the stored NH3 can timely react with NO to keep high NO conversion if the quantity of NO was excessive or NH3 was insufficient even though the temperature has not reached the optimum active temperature range. However, the stored NH3 reduced and the catalytic efficiency could not keep when the temperature increased. The above phenomena have important instructive significance to the treatment of NH3 slip caused due to excessive ammonia spraying by adjusting and controlling NH3/NO ratio to maintain high NO conversion in the practical SCR engineering. 3.1.2 The amount of catalytic ammonia storage/release The above results and analyses indicated that the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst has NH3 storage/release characteristics. Nevertheless, the data acquired via taking NO as the molecular probe cannot calculate the practical quantity of catalytic NH3 release directly. Learn from the principle of Thermo Gravimetry (TG), Constant Temperature Flow Field was designed to quantitatively research the NH3 storage/release characteristics of CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 by using pure ammonia as the incoming gas. As illustrated in Fig. 5 , the storage capacity of saturated NH3 decreases when the temperature increased. It was due to the thermal vibration and kinetic energy of ammonia molecules increased with the increase of temperature. Meanwhile, the reaction between NH3 and the catalyst was weakened, which resulted in reduced NH3 storage. However, through observation also found that the saturated NH3 storage capacity at 350 °C was greater than that at 300 °C. It was not consistent with the trend mentioned above, which was due to the increased activity of ammonia adsorption sites. NH3 can be stored through interaction with acid sites. The interaction strength was related to factors such as acid site species and temperature [37]. According to Langmuir adsorption kinetics theory [38,39], adsorption activation energy is the determinant restricting adsorption behavior. As the temperature increased, the adsorption rate was accelerated, resulting in the increase of balanced coverage and ammonia storage. It could be inferred that CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst had acid sites with high adsorption activation energy which could be fully activated at about 350 °C. NH3 was chemically adsorbed on the active site of the catalyst, which was easy to participate in reaction, this was why the catalyst achieved excellent catalytic activity at this temperature. In addition, from the kinetics perspective, storage rate at 100 °C was higher than that at 50 °C, however it was also higher than that at 150 °C in 20 min. It may be due to the adsorption of multiple acid sites. Among them, weak acid sites and strong acid sites make the relationship between its adsorption rate and temperature may not be linear. That is, ammonia storage of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst was affected by the activation of the active site and the thermal vibration at the same time. The valve was closed after the pure ammonia storage was saturated. Then the reactor was exposed to the atmosphere. Results indicated that part stored ammonia was unstable and would slip from the catalyst under air atmosphere. The total NH3 storage capacity finally reached a metastable state after unstable NH3 released. This was because the partial pressure of NH3 at atmospheric pressure was lower than that under pure NH3 atmosphere. In other words, in the process of re-establishing equilibrium after the change of partial pressure of NH3 in the system, weak NH3 storage such as physical storage was easy to be released [40].The catalytic saturation storage of pure NH3, the stable storage of NH3 under an air atmosphere, and the desorption of NH3 is listed as shown in Table 1 . Combined with the BET data in Table S1 (Support information), the stable ammonia storage amount per specific surface area of the catalyst was 27 μmol m−2. The data are shown that the ammonia desorption declined with the increase of temperature. This may be because weakly-stored ammonia decreased with the increase of the temperature. In summary, through adjusting ammonia injection time and temperature, the behaviors of ammonia storage/release could be controlled. The experiment of ammonia release with the increased temperature was designed to investigate the storage forms of ammonia. The catalyst was pretreated with saturated storage of pure ammonia at 50 °C. Fig. 6 showed the mass change of the catalyst during the heating process. According to slope change of the curve, the ammonia release curve could be divided into two temperature ranges. The first range was 50 °C–200 °C and the amount of released ammonia was about 1.17 mmol g−1. The ammonia release curve over this range could be fitted to two lines with different slopes. The higher slope was mainly caused by the release of physically stored ammonia, such as in the form of pocket-stored in the pores of catalyst. In the part with a lower slope, ammonia release decreased due to the decrease of physical storage ammonia, and there was also a partial release of ammonia stored at the weakly acid sites. In other words, the ammonia released between 50 °C and 200 °C was mainly weakly stored-ammonia. The second range was 200 °C–400 °C and the amount of ammonia release was 0.47 mmol g−1. The increase in temperature caused intensification of vibration of the ammonia molecule, breaking the force with the active sites and releasing, and the ammonia release curve was gradually stabilized after 350 °C. It can be inferred that the ammonia released between 200 °C and 400 °C was mainly strong stored-ammonia. Accordingly, the approximate amount of strong stored-ammonia was 0.47 mmol g−1. Due to the presence of both weak ammonia storage and strong ammonia storage in the catalyst at the same time, the anomaly phenomenon of 300 °C–400 °C in Fig. 5 could be intuitively explained. The activation of the acid site after 300 °C led to the increase of strong stored-ammonia. Conversely, the amount of weakly stored-ammonia decreased as the temperature increasing. The increase of strong stored-ammonia was faster than the decrease of weak storage ammonia, which led to the increase of total storage ammonia. However, when the temperature was raised from 350 °C to 400 °C, the increase of strong stored-ammonia was insufficient to offset the reduction of the weakly-stored ammonia although the active sites were sufficiently activated. Hence, the total ammonia storage amount of the catalyst showed a downward trend at 400 °C. The “catalytic activity delay experiment” was designed to investigate whether the ammonia stored could be effectively released to participate into NH3-SCR reaction. Fig. 7 (a) showed the variation of NO conversion rate with time after injection of reaction gas (NO, O2 and N2). The results showed that the catalytic NO conversion remains at about 100 % for a period at 300 °C, 350 °C and 400 °C, and the delay time shortened with temperature increasing. Although this is not consistent with the change of saturated ammonia storage measured in the Constant Temperature Flow Field, the intensification of molecular vibration caused by the increase of temperature would also lead to the release of a large amount of stored ammonia that did not participate in the reaction. In Fig. 7(b), N2 was injected and purged for 1 h after saturated ammonia storage to purge physically stored ammonia, then introduced the reaction gas. The figure showed that the delay time at each temperature decreased compared that without N2 purge. This indicated that partial weakly-stored ammonia could react with NO timely if reducing agent is insufficient in NH3-SCR reaction. At the same time, it was found that the decrease rate of the catalytic activity got lower with increasing the temperature. This is ascribed to the increase of strongly stored ammonia caused by the activation of acid site. Partial strongly-stored ammonia may not react with NO instantly while could release slowly via induced by NO and compensate catalytic activity to some extent. Combing Fig. 7(a) and (b), it was found that the change curve of the NO conversion with time at 250 °C was different from other curves. The NO conversion of the catalyst did not reach the maximum immediately as soon as reaction gas injection, but had an ascending trend. This phenomenon could be explained by the reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR [41]. The gas phase NO was adsorbed onto the surface active site and then reacted with stored ammonia. When the temperature is low (250 °C), the thermal vibration of NO molecule is weak, resulting in the low contact frequency between the molecule and the catalyst surface. It took a certain time for the adsorption of NO to reach the equilibrium reaction amount on the active sites, so as to achieve a high NO conversion. That was to say, the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst mainly followed the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism during the NH3-SCR reaction. Furthermore, the effect of GHSV on the effective release of the stored ammonia was studied. The reaction temperature was kept at 300 °C and adjusted the GHSV to 4000 h−1, 8000 h−1 and 16,000 h−1 respectively. Fig. 8 described the NO conversion at different GHSV. It was found that the curve change trend under GHSV of 16,000 h−1 was similar with that at 250 °C in Fig. 7. The NO conversion of the catalyst showed a hillside trend. Similar to 250 °C, due to increase of GHSV, NO molecules could not adsorb easily on the active sites. Meanwhile, the delay time shortened with the increase of GHSV. This was because partially stored ammonia may escape before reacting with NO if GHSV was too high. Therefore, it is crucial to control the GHSV reasonably in order to make the stored ammonia release effectively. 3.2 Catalytic characterization 3.2.1 XRD The unique storage/release characteristics of CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst may be related to the crystal structure of the material. The X-ray diffraction pattern of CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst was displayed in Fig. 9 . The pattern exhibited intensive diffraction peaks at 2 θ of 25.3, 36.9, 37.8, 38.6, 48.0, 53.9, 55.1, 62.7, 68.8, 70.3, 75.0 and 82.7, which corresponded to the (101), (103), (004), (112), (200), (105), (211), (204), (116), (220), (215) and (224) planes diffraction of the anatase structure of TiO2. The calculated cell constant was a = 0.3788 nm, b = 0.3802 nm and c = 0.9511 nm, which was similar with the constant of the standard anatase card (JCPDS 21-1272), indicating that the incorporation of Ce, Sn, Mo did not change the crystalline phase of anatase TiO2. It could be inferred that the metal oxide existed on the surface of the carrier was in a highly dispersed state. This was beneficial to increase the amount of acid sites on the surface to increase the amount of ammonia storage. 3.2.2 NH3-TPD Surface acidity of the catalyst is critical for the behavior of ammonia storage/release. The NH3-TPD curve and the acid quantity of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst were shown as Fig. 10 . Results showed that the catalyst had two desorption peaks in the range of temperature 50 °C–400 °C, which was around 91.71 °C and 285.52 °C respectively. The desorption peak of the former was mainly related to weak acid sites while desorption peak of the latter was mainly related to strong acid sites. In addition, the weak acid quantity and the strong acid quantity of CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst were 2.53 mmol g−1 and 1.61 mmol g−1, respectively. Moreover, comparing with the results obtained in Fig. 3, it was found that the catalyst released large quantities of stored ammonia at 250 °C when excess NO was introduced. The release peak of the catalyst was at 285 °C in Fig. 10, indicating that excess NO induced premature release of stored ammonia. 3.2.3 BET, SEM results There was a large quantity of weakly stored ammonia at low temperature which may be related to the porous structure of the catalyst. Fig. 11 depicted the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst. The results showed that there was a significant hysteresis loop in the isotherm adsorption-desorption curve. The hysteresis loop was Type H3 loop according to the IUPAC classification [42]. This may be due to the mass transfer effect of the plate-like pore structure formed by particle aggregation, which facilitated the capillary condensation of ammonia. Based on Kelvin equation [43], when the partial pressure of NH3 is more than the corresponding relative pressure of the critical radius, gaseous NH3 will condense into droplets and adhere to the pores of the catalyst. The gas ammonia liquefies continuously and sticks to the pores, the effective distance between particles decreases gradually, and the partial pressure of ammonia decreases continuously until it reaches the relative pressure corresponding to the critical radius of the pores. Provided that the temperature is too high or the partial pressure of NH3 is less than the relative pressure corresponding to the critical radius, the liquid NH3 would vaporize and slip from the catalyst. Fig. 12 showed the SEM photos of CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst. The results showed that the microscopic particles and pores were uniformly distributed, which provided a favorable physical space for the NH3 storage and release behavior. As shown in Fig. S3 (Support information), the pore structure and size distribution were analyzed via the method of BJH. The results showed that the pore size distribution was relatively concentrated, focusing on the value of 8.56 nm. 3.2.4 In situ DRIFT spectra To explore the storage morphology and activation forms of ammonia on the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst, in situ DRIFT technique was performed. As shown in Fig. 13 , the characteristic bands appeared at wave numbers of 3394, 3263, 3166, 1670, 1601, 1440 and 1256 cm−1 respectively. Among them, the bands at wavenumbers of 1440 and 1670 cm−1 were mainly attributed to the chemical bond symmetry and asymmetric stretching vibration of NH4 +* species adsorbed on the B-acid sites of catalyst [44–46]. The band at the wavenumber of 1256 cm−1 might be ascribed to the symmetric stretching of the coordinated NH3 bound to the CeOTi L-acid sites [22,47,48]. The band at 1601 cm−1 was attributed to the asymmetric vibration of the NH bond of the coordinated NH3 on the TiOTi L-acid sites [47,49–51]. Besides, the bands at the wavenumbers of 3394, 3263 and 3166 cm−1 were caused by the symmetric NH stretching vibration of coordinated NH3 on L-acid sites [52,53]. It was observed that a large amount of NH4+* species was stored on the B-acid sites in the catalyst at low temperatures. However, the NH4+* specie was difficult to bind at B-acid sites as the temperature increased. The same phenomenon could be observed in coordinated NH3 specie bound on the TiOTi L-acid sites. In contrast, there was almost no coordinated NH3 bound to the CeOTi L-acid sites at 50 °C but this specie could be clearly observed as the temperature raised. In other words, the coordinated NH3 bound to the Ce-O-Ti L-acid sites could be stably present at high temperatures. It can be inferred that the doping of Ce provided more L-acid sites and increased the amount of strong stored-ammonia. To sum up, ammonia mainly existed in the form of NH4 +* and coordinated NH3 species when the catalyst performed a large amount of ammonia storage behavior at low temperature and low activity window. However, when the temperature rose to the high activity window of 300 °C and above, the species of NH4 +* at low temperature may partially switch to the coordinated NH3 species. 4 Conclusion The specific ammonia storage/release behaviors of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalysts caused the deNOx efficiency greater than theoretical maximum value in the active temperature range of 250 °C–450 °C under low NH3/NO ratios (0.5−0.9). The stored-ammonia amount decreased as temperature increased. Weak stored-ammonia mainly stored in physical form and adsorbed at weak acid sites at low temperature. As the temperature rose, strong acid sites were activated, part of the weak stored-ammonia slipped and partly transformed into strong stored-ammonia. Weak stored-ammonia could release effectively and react with NO instantly if reducing agent is insufficient. In contrast, partially strong stored-ammonia released slowly to compensate catalytic activity through being induced by NO. The GHSV also has an effect on the effective release of the stored-ammonia. XRD pattern showed that the metal oxide of Ce, Sn and Mo were in a highly dispersed state on the surface of the carrier, which was beneficial to increase the amount of acid sites on the surface to increase the amount of ammonia storage. BET and SEM profiles indicated uniform hole distribution of the catalyst, which was conducive to increase the ammonia storage capability of the catalyst. in situ DRIFT analysis shown that ammonia was mainly present on the catalyst as NH4 +* and coordinated NH3 species. The amount of NH4 +* and coordinated NH3 bound on the TiOTi L-acid sites decreased while the amount of coordinated NH3 bound on the CeOTi L-acid sites increased with temperature increasing, allowing the catalytic reaction to proceed faster. The above conclusions have important instructive significance to the treatment of NH3 slip in the practical SCR engineering through adjusting the temperature and the amount of ammonia spraying to maintain high NO conversion. coredata.dc:description: This work explored the ammonia storage/release behaviors of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst in selective catalytic reduction of NO. Results displayed that the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 performed much higher NO removal rate than the theoretical maximum if the NH3/NO ratio was lower than one, which was due to the ammonia storage/release behaviors. The ammonia storing was more likely to occur at low temperatures, and the storage capacity of the catalyst reached 27 μmol m−2 at 50 °C. Moreover, ammonia exists mainly on physical form of temperatures below 250 °C and is adsorbed in weakly acidic sites; while high temperature strengthen activation of strong acid sites, resulting in increasing the ammonia storage at 350 °C. NH3-TPD results showed two peaks of ammonia desorption, indicating the weak and strong acid sites of the catalyst. The ammonia storage/release curves at Constant Temperature Flow Field were asymmetric and BET isotherm showed Type H3 hysteresis loop, which was caused by mass transfer in the plate-like pore structure formed by the particle polymerization. The porous structure and highly dispersed active components were beneficial for storing ammonia. The effective utilization ratio of the stored ammonia decreased with the increasing temperature and GHSV.
coredata.dc:title: Ammonia storage/release behaviors of the CeSn0.2Mo0.6Ox/TiO2 catalyst in selective catalytic reduction of NO
